meaningMnemonic: Remember how 手 can mean a "doer"? Now, what do you think your <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> might be? It’s someone who shares the same activities or tasks with you. This person could be your <vocabulary>partner</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>companion</vocabulary>, or even an <vocabulary>opponent</vocabulary> in certain situations.
readingMnemonic:
The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way: 

Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: <reading>I</reading> (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."
